posts.name: Blue Star Donuts
posts.note: Blue Star Donuts is an upmarket brioche-donut bakery features creative flavors and organic, locally sourced ingredients. Blue Star Donuts makes the best apple fritters I have ever eaten, and I'm in my mid 50's. I've even gone back a second or third, or more times their donuts rock.

posts.name: Bunk Sandwiches
posts.note: Bunk's signature sandwiches - such as the Pork Belly Cubano, the Meatball Parmigiana Hero, and the Pulled Pork with Apple Cabbage Slaw - have garnered national media attention. I had to order the Pork Belly Cubano with ham, pork belly, and pork shoulder roast, swiss cheese, mustard, and pickles from their food truck at XOXO Festival.

posts.name: Chicken and Guns
posts.note: Chicken and Guns serves Oak Fired Latin Chicken. They only use naturally raised chickens from Scratch Farms in Canby, OR. All ingredients are sourced locally when possible. Their chicken and sides are great and would eat there again.

posts.name: The Fried Onion
posts.note: The Fried Onion is a New York City street food. The Moussa is grilled onions, roasted red peppers, buffalo chicken, and pastrami sandwich. From their food stand at XOXO Festival, they served egg and cheese sandwiches with home-made basil pesto which I had for breakfast at least two days while at XOXO.

posts.name: Grilled Cheese Grill
posts.note: Grilled Cheese Grill is a hopping eatery housed in a converted school bus serving creative spins on the grilled cheese. The line was long and made other choices for my meals at XOXO Festival.

posts.name: Interurban
posts.note: Interurban is a bustling two-story saloon with retro hardwood decor serving craft cocktails and upscale bar snacks.

posts.name: Kenny & Zuke's Delicatessen
posts.note: Kenny and Zuke's Delicatessen is a buy spot serving a signature pastrami, bagels, and other deli fare in a roomy, light-filled space. You need to order the Jeremy which is mac and cheese with pastrami.

posts.name: Kim Jong Grillin’
posts.note: Kim Jong Grillin’ is possibly the best-named cart ever, with addictive Korean street food. AFter waiting in line, I ordered the Bibim Box which contains excellent bulgogi beef over fried rice, and it's topped with a fried egg.

posts.name: Lardo
posts.note: Lardo's a former food truck turned small, hip pork-centered sandwich shop, with draft beers and outdoor patio. They are known for their burgers and have great fries.

posts.name: Laurelhurst Market
posts.note: Laurelhurst Market is a butcher shop/steakhouse providing unusual cuts, house-cured meats, and craft drinks in industrial digs.

posts.name: Le Pigeon
posts.note: Le Pigeon has a rotating menu of creative French-inspired fare served at communal tables or the bar in a snug room.

posts.name: Lincoln Restaurant
posts.note: Spare, polished bistro bar serving locally sourced dishes from an open kitchen. You need to order the elk if it's available.

posts.name: Matt's BBQ
posts.add1: 4709 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
posts.note: The little cart makes the finest Texas ribs in the city, white-oak smoky with a ribbon of aching pink and tenderness beneath. His chili-spiked hot links have a whiplash snap, and you could die of heartbreak between bites of the succulent beef brisket, whose beautifully thick bark now comes equipped with piquant salt-and-pepper bite.

posts.name: The Meadow
posts.note: The Meadow, salt, chocolate, bitters, and salt blocks.

posts.name: Michael's Italian Beef & Sausage Co.
posts.note: Quick-serve destination for Chicago-style sandwiches plus Italian sausage and other casual fare such as hot dogs.

posts.name: Ned Ludd
posts.add1: 3925 NE Martin Luther King Jr Blvd
posts.note: Inventive New American dishes cooked in wood-fired oven and served in small, elegantly rustic room. Monday night only 100 wood oven pizza's. Next time I'm in town and stay at my usual AirBnB because I found out it's a block away.

posts.name: Nong’s Khao Man Gai
posts.note: The namesake Khao Man Gai (Thai chicken and rice wrapped in butcher paper) draws crowds to this cart. Nong’s Khao Man Gai has some of the best chicken and rice I have ever had and still think about it months later.

posts.name: Olympic Provisions
posts.note: House-made charcuterie and European-style meals provided in an industrial space with a to-go counter.

posts.name: The Original Dinerant
posts.note: Updated diner meals dished out in a modern setting that's open late, with booths and a candlelit bar. You have to try the cheeseburger slider in a donuts. Also, try the chicken thigh chicken waffles that has cheese and jalapeno inside it.

posts.name: PDX671
posts.note: Taking its name from Portland's airport code and the island of Guam's area code, PDX671 is a food cart that fuses seasonal ingredients of the Pacific Northwest with flavors and cooking techniques of Guam. You need to order yourself some Shrimp Fritters as an appetizer and then for your meal the chicken and rice.

posts.name: Podnah's Pit Barbecue
posts.note: Smoked Texas-style barbecue and sides served in a simple, spacious restaurant with wood tables & bar. Been told you need to get a sampler platter.

posts.name: Pok Pok
posts.note: Creative Thai street food like fish-sauce wings and unique beverages served at a small, modern spot. I've ordered their 'Ike’s Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings' which are fresh whole natural chicken wings marinated in fish sauce and sugar, deep fried, tossed in caramelized Vietnamese fish sauce and garlic and served with Cu Cai (pickled vegetables.)  Another great dish to share is the 'Mu Paa Kham Waan Boar' collar meat rubbed with garlic, coriander root and black pepper, glazed with soy and sugar, grilled over charcoal and served with chilled mustard greens and a spicy chili/lime/garlic sauce. You need to try their drinking vinegars. My favorite is there blackberry drinking vinegar.

posts.name: Salt & Straw
posts.note: They love exploring fun, interesting new ice cream flavors and my favorite so far is the salted Carmel. All their flavors are great it all depends on what you're in the mode to eat. My favorite is their Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons in a cup.

posts.name: Swiss Hibiscus
posts.note: Classic Swiss dishes and other European eats whipped up in a petite, low-key bistro with a patio.

posts.name: Tin Shed Garden Cafe
posts.note: Small, dog-friendly place specializing in American food, offering a covered patio and a canine menu. They offer wonderful veggie dishes.
